Recommendation: Level 3: Ban arrivals from some regions

Level.LevelDesc: Level 3: Ban arrivals from some regions

Notes.Note: Still current:    In response to the new variant of COVID-19 in South Africa, there are restrictions on passengers arriving in the UK from South Africa. Direct flights between South Africa and the UK have been suspended. Visitors arriving into England who have been in or transited through South Africa in the previous 10 days will not be permitted entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226123110/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-africa

You cannot currently enter the UK if you’ve been in or through a country on the banned travel list (sometimes known as the ‘red list’) in the last 10 days, unless you’re British, Irish or you have the right to live in the UK.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217091929/https://www.gov.uk/uk-border-control?priority-taxon=774cee22-d896-44c1-a611-e3109cce8eae

Announced Feb 9: "All travellers entering the UK will be required to take two coronavirus tests while quarantining in an attempt to prevent variants entering the country.  Arrivals will be required to get a test on days two and eight of their 10-day quarantine period, whether they are isolating at home or in a hotel."     http://web.archive.org/web/20210209111950/https://www.bbc.com/news/business-55989921
See C1 sources

Visitors arriving into the UK who have been in or transited through South Africa in the previous 10 days will not be permitted entry    https://web.archive.org/web/20210129100757/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-africa

From the 18th January, all travel corridors to close and you must self-isolate after arriving in the UK, even if you have tested negative. Most people travelling to the UK from abroad need proof of a negative coronavirus (COVID-19) test result.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124212610/https://www.gov.uk/coronavirus

travel restrictions extended to southern African countries from 4am Saturday 9 January (2021) to protect against the spread of a new COVID-19 variant initially detected in South Africa      https://web.archive.org/web/20210110180332/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/travel-restrictions-update-south-africa-ban-extended-israel-and-jerusalem-removed-from-travel-corridors-list
Covid-19: Travellers to UK will need to show negative test result https://web.archive.org/web/20210108163843/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-55582116
Covid-19: Travellers to UK will need to show negative test result          https://web.archive.org/web/20210108163843/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-55582116

passengers travelling from South Africa into England from 9am Thursday 24 December will not be permitted to enter, reflecting increased risk from new strain of coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115174613/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/travel-ban-implemented-to-protect-public-health-following-south-africa-covid-19-outbreak

People living in a tier 4 area must not travel abroad unless legally permitted to do so. People visiting the UK and in a Tier 4 areas may return home.   A number of countries have subjected the UK to travel bans due to the emergence of a new Covid strain.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201221220916/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-safer-travel-guidance-for-passengers  http://web.archive.org/web/20201221230824/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-55385768

England introduces national lockdown on 5 November, and a ban on people travelling internationally except for essential work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201104133027/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/new-national-restrictions-from-5-november#travel

England introduces national lockdown on 5 November, and a ban on people travelling internationally except for essential work.                https://web.archive.org/web/20201104133027/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/new-national-restrictions-from-5-november#travel

National lockdown comes into effect in England on 5 November. Changes to international travel are introduced, as people are not allowed to travel internationally except for essential travel for work. This is different to the previous lockdown which did not forbid citizens from leaving the country.    "Overnight stays and holidays away from primary residences will not be allowed- including holidays in the UK and abroad"      https://web.archive.org/web/20201104133027/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/new-national-restrictions-from-5-november#travel
No change in policy.
no changes recorded.
no changes recorded.

Travellers to Scotland from Italy, San Marino and the Vatican will soon have to self-isolate for 14 days after arrival.    The changes come into effect at 4am on Sunday and are being brought in due to “significant increases” in coronavirus cases.    Meanwhile, those arriving from mainland Greece and the Greek islands, except Mykonos, will no longer need to quarantine as of the same time due to the low number of cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201021105930/https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/18799696.coronavirus-italy-san-marino-vatican-city-added-scotlands-travel-quarantine-list/

People entering Wales are required to self isolate for two weeks (and have been required to since 8th June)  https://web.archive.org/web/20201017121734/https://gov.wales/written-statement-health-protection-coronavirus-public-health-information-persons-travelling-wales  https://web.archive.org/web/20201017121754/https://senedd.wales/laid%20documents/sub-ld13590-em/sub-ld13590-em-e.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20201017113700/https://gov.wales/written-statement-health-protection-coronavirus-international-travel-wales-amendments-8
Quarantine on arrival still in place for most countries. https://web.archive.org/web/20201004231526/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-corridors

Depending on the rates of the virus, citizens in very high alert level areas are recommended to stay at home and not leave the country. However, a travel ban has not been imposed, hence this is coded as 2.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201012181705/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/prime-minister-announces-new-local-covid-alert-levels

still current - "You must self-isolate for 14 full days if you arrive in Scotland from a country outside the Common Travel Area (UK, Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man). This is to protect against the risk of imported cases of coronavirus."     http://web.archive.org/web/20201006004150/https://www.gov.scot/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-public-health-checks-at-borders/

No change in policy     http://web.archive.org/web/20200922164730/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-how-to-self-isolate-when-you-travel-to-the-uk/coronavirus-covid-19-how-to-self-isolate-when-you-travel-to-the-uk
Still current       http://web.archive.org/web/20200927184524/https://www.gov.scot/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-public-health-checks-at-borders/
Quarantine on arrival still in place for most countries. https://web.archive.org/web/20201004231526/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-corridors

Still current, "The regulations mean that you must self-isolate for 14 days if you return to Northern Ireland from a country outside the Common Travel Area (CTA) unless you are travelling from, or transiting through, a low to medium risk country that is exempt."     http://web.archive.org/web/20201006010843/https://www.nidirect.gov.uk/articles/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-advice

From 4 September, Wales has decided to remove Portugal from it's list of quarantine exempted countries, as well as Gibraltar, French Polynesia and the Greek islands of Mykonos, Zakynthos, Lesvos, Paros and Antiparos and Crete. A mandatory 14-day quarantine is now required for these countries and territories. This differs from the UK Gov list from Westminster.     https://archive.vn/FMkeR
From 29 August, travellers arriving to Scotland from Czech Republic and Jamaica are required to self-isolate for 14 days.   https://archive.vn/to2Eb

From 4am on 22 August, travellers into the UK from Austria, Switzerland, Croatia and Trinidad & Tobago will be required to self-isolate for 14 days on entry to the UK.   Arrivals from Portugal on 22 of August and later are no longer required to self-isolate (but if they returned on the 21 August, they ARE required to self-isolate.     http://archive.vn/eSw5q
From today, 8 August, Belgium, Andorra and the Bahamas have been added to the 14 day quarantine requirement list for international travel.     http://archive.vn/MqJBM

Foreign nationals arriving to the UK still have to self-quarantine for 14 days unless they are on a list of countries that are exempt from this requirement:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200722164341/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-corridors#exemption-rules

In addition to the mandatory quarantines from countries designated by the Scottish Government  (https://www.gov.scot/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-public-health-checks-at-borders/pages/exemptions/)  Scotland has issued a strong advisory against travel between England and Scotland, particularly between Northern England and the Scottish border, due to large outbreaks in Northern England cities.     http://archive.vn/sQ1ET

Foreign nationals arriving to the UK still have to self-quarantine for 14 days unless they are on a list of countries that are exempt from this requirement:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200722164341/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-corridors#exemption-rules

July 10  The rules are being relaxed for arrivals from 75 countries and British overseas territories, who do not need to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival in England. Rules in England are different to other devolved nations. Quarantine is still mandatory for any arrival not on the list of exemptions listed on government website.    BBC News: https://web.archive.org/web/20200713032443/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-53358870    Government source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200712181352/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-corridors

From 10 July, If you are travelling to Scotland from any of the 39 places the UK Government has rated as green, we will not require you to self-isolate upon arrival in Scotland. A full list of those countries will be published on our website – however they include Germany, Austria, Norway and Malta. Scotland will also lift quarantine for the countries on the amber list that have a prevalence below or not significantly higher than Scotland. That list includes France, Greece, the Netherlands, Italy, and Poland. This list DOES NOT include Spain or Serbia at this time, and will be reassessed on 20 July, and the 14 day quarantine will still remain for all other countries on the amber list where the prevalence is higher than Scotland.     http://archive.vn/H3oHA

Most foreign nationals arriving to the UK still have to self-quarantine for 14 days; however, there is a list of countries that are exempt from this requirement:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200713140548/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-corridors

8 June    Passengers arriving in the UK will be required to self-isolate for 14 days. These quarantine rules are the same as the ones set by UK NAT GOV at this particular time, but Wales holds the authority and autonomy to alter the list of countries for which travellers can and cannot enter Wales, regardless of what is on the list for England, set by Westminster.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200611155101/https://homeofficemedia.blog.gov.uk/2020/05/22/factsheet-new-public-health-measures-at-the-uk-border-to-help-fight-coronavirus/    https://archive.vn/D64LN

Passengers arriving in the UK will be required to self-isolate for 14 days. The new regime will be in place across the United Kingdom, although enforcement measures will be set individually by the Devolved Administrations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200611155101/https://homeofficemedia.blog.gov.uk/2020/05/22/factsheet-new-public-health-measures-at-the-uk-border-to-help-fight-coronavirus/

Passengers arriving in the UK will be required to self-isolate for 14 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200611155101/https://homeofficemedia.blog.gov.uk/2020/05/22/factsheet-new-public-health-measures-at-the-uk-border-to-help-fight-coronavirus/

8 June    Passengers arriving in the UK will be required to self-isolate for 14 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200611155101/https://homeofficemedia.blog.gov.uk/2020/05/22/factsheet-new-public-health-measures-at-the-uk-border-to-help-fight-coronavirus/

A 14 day period of self-isolation for those arriving in Scotland from outside the Common Travel Area is now mandatory and being enforced. (The list of countries on the Common Travel Area can be found on the GOV.uk website).     http://archive.vn/wip/XQ2L4

21 May  Thermal imaging screening is trialled at Heathrow Airport, but no evidence that this is part of a national government mandated policy, so not coded as such.    Heathrow media centre source:https://web.archive.org/web/20200713134211/https://mediacentre.heathrow.com/pressrelease/details/81/Corporate-operational-24/12312

'UK airlines say they have been told the government will bring in a 14-day quarantine for anyone arriving in the UK from any country apart from the Republic of Ireland in response to the coronavirus pandemic.'  Due to begin at the end of May (no official announcement yet, and not clear what is due to happen for other arrivals (Eurostar/ ferry).    https://web.archive.org/web/20200509161824/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-52594023

9 May  'UK airlines say they have been told the government will bring in a 14-day quarantine for anyone arriving in the UK from any country apart from the Republic of Ireland in response to the coronavirus pandemic.'  Due to begin at the end of May (no official announcement yet, and not clear what is due to happen for other arrivals (Eurostar/ ferry).    https://web.archive.org/web/20200509161824/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-52594023
https://web.archive.org/web/20200426105659/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-advice-novel-coronavirus  No restriction on entry into the UK.

24 April  No restriction on entry into the UK. “No screening of passengers entering the UK for now” (Sky News)    Government Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200426105659/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-advice-novel-coronavirus     Sky News: https://web.archive.org/web/20200525053328/https://news.sky.com/story/coronavirus-no-covid-19-screening-of-passengers-arriving-in-the-uk-for-now-11978463

Ninety-seven percent of flights at Belfast International Airport have been grounded since Northern Ireland went into lockdown, new figures have revealed.    A spokesperson for Belfast International Airport said the airport remains "open and appropriately staffed 24/7" during the pandemic crisis.    https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/northern-ireland/97-of-belfast-international-airport-flights-off-since-coronavirus-lockdown-began-39149955.html
*Earlier entered as 1 by another contributor (just for this day, with no entries for 5 days before), but found no apparent introduction of screenings*
